dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, we've seen amazing progress against HIV/AIDS, right? Like, over the last three decades. But this article, it really argues that we shouldn't get complacent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, we've seen amazing progress against H I V A I D S, right? Like, over the last three decades. But this article, it really argues that we shouldn't get complacent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And yet, despite the remarkable progress made during the last three decades or perhaps because of it we must avoid the temptation to declare the fight against AIDS almost over.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. It's, um, it's a really important point. The temptation is there to think the fight's almost over, but in so many parts of the world, like, the hardest work is actually just starting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. It's, um, it's a really important point. The temptation is there to think the fight's almost over, but in so many parts of the world, like, the hardest work is actually just starting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In many parts of the world, the hardest work is just beginning.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild, because, remember the Millennium Development Goals? Those really made reducing HIV a top priority, right? And we saw huge advances.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, because, remember the Millennium Development Goals? Those really made reducing H I V a top priority, right? And we saw huge advances.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since the turn of the century, many of the advances against HIV were enabled by the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), a 15-year policy roadmap that made reducing the spread of the virus a top priority.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. But then, when the Sustainable Development Goals came in, HIV kinda shifted from being a standalone goal to just *one* of 169 targets. And, uh, that's where this "false sense of accomplishment" seems to have crept in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. But then, when the Sustainable Development Goals came in, H I V kinda shifted from being a standalone goal to just one of one hundred sixty nine targets. And, uh, that's where this false sense of accomplishment seems to have crept in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: when the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) succeeded the MDGs in 2015, ending AIDS was no longer a standalone goal. Rather, further progress had become one of 169 targets that the SDGs are supposed to achieve by 2030. ... But the transition from a goal to a target, combined with steep declines in AIDS-related deaths, has lulled us into a false sense of accomplishment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? People hear about declining deaths, and they just assume it's, like, nearing its end. But the article says that's just not true. It's so much more complex than just, you know, biomedical responses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? People hear about declining deaths, and they just assume it's, like, nearing its end. But the article says that's just not true. It's so much more complex than just, you know, biomedical responses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, many argue that AIDS is nearing its end. Unfortunately, nothing could be further from the truth. HIV is a complex issue. Biomedical responses are vital to disease control, but if people cannot access medicine or preventive services, even the best-designed initiatives will fail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. It's not just about medicine, is it? A lot of the obstacles are actually tied to, uh, political, economic, and social marginalization. Like, think about gender inequality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. It's not just about medicine, is it? A lot of the obstacles are actually tied to, uh, political, economic, and social marginalization. Like, think about gender inequality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whats more, the obstacles to treatment often have nothing to do with health care, but rather, are tied to political, economic, and social marginalization.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, where women might not even have a say over, um, when or with whom they have sex. How do you lower infection rates then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, where women might not even have a say over, um, when or with whom they have sex. How do you lower infection rates then?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, it can be difficult to lower rates of infection in countries where gender inequality prevents women from making decisions about when, where, and even with whom they have sex.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. And while it's fantastic that in many places HIV is now a chronic, manageable disease – which is huge, by the way – millions still don't know their status or get the support they need.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. And while it's fantastic that in many places H I V is now a chronic, manageable disease - which is huge, by the way - millions still don't know their status or get the support they need.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, in many parts of the world, HIV is now considered a chronic disease manageable with medication and lifestyle changes; that fact alone is worthy of celebration. Nonetheless, millions of people still do not know their HIV status or cannot get the support they need when they test positive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, the key takeaway here is really, uh, about integrating the fight against HIV into broader sustainable development planning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the key takeaway here is really, uh, about integrating the fight against H I V into broader sustainable development planning.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Above all, that means integrating the struggle against HIV more fully into sustainable-development planning.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. If governments are working on social protection or food security, HIV responses need to be part of that plan. You can't separate it from things like poverty or, uh, gender bias.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. If governments are working on social protection or food security, H I V responses need to be part of that plan. You can't separate it from things like poverty or, uh, gender bias.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When governments work to implement the SDGs in areas like social protection, food security, and gender-based violence, HIV responses must also be part of their plans. Only by linking HIV strategies to the issues that predispose people to infection such as poverty, education, and gender bias can we hope for a future free from AIDS for everyone, everywhere.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You see it so clearly, like, with that recent situation in Tanzania. [interrupts] A city official targeting LGBT individuals, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You see it so clearly, like, with that recent situation in Tanzania. A city official targeting L G B T individuals, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, just last month in Tanzania, hundreds of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) people were forced into hiding after a city official in Dar es Salaam warned that a taskforce was being created to identify and punish gay people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, which is terrifying. Because LGBT groups are often on the front lines of prevention efforts there. So, any threat to their human rights, uh, directly impacts the HIV response.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, which is terrifying. Because L G B T groups are often on the front lines of prevention efforts there. So, any threat to their human rights, uh, directly impacts the H I V response.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With LGBT groups on the frontlines of Tanzanias HIV-prevention efforts, any threat to their members human rights is also a threat to the HIV response.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just Tanzania. The article points out the situation in the Middle East and North Africa is dire, too, with forced sex increasing women's risk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just Tanzania. The article points out the situation in the Middle East and North Africa is dire, too, with forced sex increasing women's risk.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nor is Tanzania the exception. On the contrary, as a recent report by my organization highlights, the situation is especially dire in the Middle East and North Africa, where forced sex within and outside of marriage is pervasive. These coercive and often violent encounters increase womens risk of exposure to HIV.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It just underscores what activists have always known: you can't tackle HIV in isolation. It's connected to social, cultural, economic, and legal challenges.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It just underscores what activists have always known: you can't tackle H I V in isolation. It's connected to social, cultural, economic, and legal challenges.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Those on the frontlines of the AIDS response have always recognized that the disease cannot be overcome in isolation; rather, it must be addressed through an interconnected set of social, cultural, economic, and legal challenges.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, it's the inclusive approach that got us this far. And the SDGs' mantra is "leave no one behind," but tragically, many of the most vulnerable to HIV *are* being forgotten.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, it's the inclusive approach that got us this far. And the S D Gs mantra is leave no one behind, but tragically, many of the most vulnerable to H I V are being forgotten.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The mantra of the SDGs is leave no one behind. At the moment, however, many of those most vulnerable to HIV are being forgotten and will be left behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the article makes it pretty clear: until we address those underlying issues, until the SDGs are truly met, uh, ending the scourge of HIV/AIDS will remain elusive. We've got a long way to go.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the article makes it pretty clear: until we address those underlying issues, until the S D Gs are truly met, uh, ending the scourge of H I V A I D S will remain elusive. We've got a long way to go.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: as long as the SDGs are unmet, the goal of ending the scourge of HIV/AIDS will remain elusive. We have a long way to go before that happens.
